However, the electron-withdrawing carbonyl found in CAC may reduce the surface electron density weakening the interactions between adsorbents and adsorbates. (2) According to the results of isotherms fits, it can be deduced that chlorobenzene adsorption on CDC exhibits greater affinity (Lennard–Jones potential) than toluene. Furthermore, the more polarized electrons of chlorobenzene enhance the adsorbate–adsorbent interaction, which makes chlorobenzene more easily adsorbed on the adsorbent. Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are major air pollutants in indoor environments, which significantly impact indoor quality, and thus are of growing concern to human health. Due to their common use in manufacturing processes, VOCs originate from a large variety of indoor sources including building materials, furnishings, cleaning supplies and pesticides and are frequently found indoors at levels exceeding those outdoors (EPA, 2007). At high levels of exposure, many VOCs are known to cause toxic effects, whereas low levels have been linked to airway inflammation and alterations in immune cell function, with a subsequent risk for development of allergies and asthma (Diez et al., 2000; Lehmann et al., 2001, 2002).
